<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 329, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 907, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 907, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 600, 764, 615]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value is necessary, take the acceleration due to gravity to be \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 615, 507, 630]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 630, 907, 660]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 660, 608, 675]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 689, 608, 704]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 704, 757, 720]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves along an arc of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(2 \mathrm{~m}\). At time \(t\) seconds, the angle \(POA\) is \(\theta\), where \(\theta = 1 - \cos 2t\), and \(A\) is a fixed point on the arc of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 121, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Show that the magnitude of the radial component of the acceleration of \(P\) when \(t = \frac{1}{6}\pi\) is \(6 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 157]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 191, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 839, 524]]<|/det|>
Find the magnitude of the transverse component of the acceleration of \(P\) when \(t = \frac{1}{6}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 508, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves on a straight line in simple harmonic motion. The centre of the motion is \(O\). The points \(A\) and \(B\) are on the line on opposite sides of \(O\) such that \(OA = 3.5 \text{ m}\) and \(OB = 1 \text{ m}\). The speed of \(P\) when it is at \(B\) is twice its speed when it is at \(A\). The maximum acceleration of \(P\) is \(1 \text{ m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 138, 156, 155]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 136, 443, 155]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(P\) when it is at \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 598, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the time taken by \(P\) to travel directly from \(A\) to \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 84, 715, 313]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 336, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
A uniform rod \(AB\) of length \(4a\) and weight \(W\) rests with the end \(A\) in contact with a rough vertical wall. A light inextensible string of length \(\frac{5}{2} a\) has one end attached to the point \(C\) on the rod, where \(AC = \frac{5}{2} a\). The other end of the string is attached to a point \(D\) on the wall, vertically above \(A\). The vertical plane containing the rod \(AB\) is perpendicular to the wall. The angle between the rod and the wall is \(\theta\), where \(\tan \theta = 2\) (see diagram). The end \(A\) of the rod is on the point of slipping down the wall and the coefficient of friction between the rod and the wall is \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 453, 628, 472]]<|/det|>
Find, in either order, the tension in the string and the value of \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 453, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
The object performs small oscillations about \(L\), with the ring above the sphere as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 104, 154, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 103, 826, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the set of possible values of \(k\) and the period of these oscillations in terms of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A fair six-sided die is thrown until a 3 or a 4 is obtained. The number of throws taken is denoted by the random variable \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 371, 139]]<|/det|>
State the mean value of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 297, 156, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 297, 698, 316]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that obtaining a 3 or a 4 takes exactly 6 throws.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 297, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 505, 153, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 505, 722, 524]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that obtaining a 3 or a 4 takes more than 4 throws.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest integer \(n\) such that the probability of obtaining a 3 or a 4 in fewer than \(n\) throws is less than 0.95.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 737, 94]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 98, 628, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{3}{4x^2} + \frac{1}{4} & 1\leqslant x\leqslant 3,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 168, 156, 186]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 168, 440, 186]]<|/det|>
Find the distribution function of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 188]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 566, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the interquartile range of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|> A large number of runners are attending a summer training camp. A random sample of 6 runners is chosen and their times to run \(1500\mathrm{m}\) at the beginning of the camp and at the end of the camp are recorded. Their times, in minutes, are shown in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 131, 866, 201]]<|/det|>
RunnerABCDEF
Time at beginning of camp3.823.623.553.713.753.92
Time at end of camp3.723.553.523.683.543.73
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 216, 920, 266]]<|/det|> The organiser of the training camp claims that a runner's time will improve by more than 0.05 minutes between the beginning and end of the camp. Assuming that differences in time over the two runs are normally distributed, test at the \(10\%\) significance level whether the organiser's claim is justified. [8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|> A random sample of 50 observations of the continuous random variable \(X\) was taken and the values are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 116, 907, 164]]<|/det|>
Interval\(0\leqslant x<0.8\)\(0.8\leqslant x<1.6\)\(1.6\leqslant x<2.4\)\(2.4\leqslant x<3.2\)\(3.2\leqslant x<4\)
Observed frequency1816862
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 178, 920, 198]]<|/det|> It is required to test the goodness of fit of the distribution with probability density function f given by <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 203, 631, 253]]<|/det|> \[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{3}{16} (4 - x)^{\frac{1}{2}} & 0\leqslant x< 4,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 876, 275]]<|/det|> The relevant expected frequencies, correct to 2 decimal places, are given in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 284, 907, 331]]<|/det|>
Interval\(0\leqslant x<0.8\)\(0.8\leqslant x<1.6\)\(1.6\leqslant x<2.4\)\(2.4\leqslant x<3.2\)\(3.2\leqslant x<4\)
Expected frequency14.2212.5410.598.184.47
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 345, 156, 364]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 345, 667, 364]]<|/det|> Show how the expected frequency for \(1.6 \leqslant x < 2.4\) is obtained. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 346, 920, 364]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 631, 92]]<|/det|>
Carry out a goodness of fit test at the \(5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> The values from a random sample of five pairs \((x, y)\) taken from a bivariate distribution are shown below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 114, 663, 163]]<|/det|>
\(x\)34468
\(y\)57\(q\)67
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 176, 653, 196]]<|/det|> The equation of the regression line of \(x\) on \(y\) is given by \(x = \frac{5}{4}y + c\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 210, 156, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 210, 479, 227]]<|/det|> Given that \(q\) is an integer, find its value. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 210, 920, 227]]<|/det|> [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 524, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 201, 122]]<|/det|>
# EITHER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 920, 234]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\), of mass \(m\), is able to move in a vertical circle on the smooth inner surface of a sphere with centre \(O\) and radius \(a\). Points \(A\) and \(B\) are on the inner surface of the sphere and \(AOB\) is a horizontal diameter. Initially, \(P\) is projected vertically downwards with speed \(\sqrt{\left(\frac{2l}{2} ag\right)}\) from \(A\) and begins to move in a vertical circle. At the lowest point of its path, vertically below \(O\), the particle \(P\) collides with a stationary particle \(Q\), of mass \(4m\), and rebounds. The speed acquired by \(Q\), as a result of the collision, is just sufficient for it to reach the point \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 247, 156, 265]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 247, 734, 265]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(P\) and the speed of \(Q\) immediately after their collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 247, 918, 265]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
In its subsequent motion, \(P\) loses contact with the inner surface of the sphere at the point \(D\), where the angle between \(OD\) and the upward vertical through \(O\) is \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 120, 154, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 248, 137]]<|/det|>
Find \(\cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 151, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
A farmer grows two different types of cherries, Type \(A\) and Type \(B\). He assumes that the masses of each type are normally distributed. He chooses a random sample of 8 cherries of Type \(A\). He finds that the sample mean mass is \(15.1 \text{g}\) and that a \(95\%\) confidence interval for the population mean mass, \(\mu \text{g}\), is \(13.5 \leqslant \mu \leqslant 16.7\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 182, 156, 200]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 182, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
Find an unbiased estimate for the population variance of the masses of cherries of Type \(A\). [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
The farmer now chooses a random sample of 6 cherries of Type \(B\) and records their masses as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 546, 707, 567]]<|/det|>
\[12.2\qquad 13.3\qquad 16.4\qquad 14.0\qquad 13.9\qquad 15.4\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 586, 153, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 586, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
Test at the \(5\%\) significance level whether the mean mass of cherries of Type \(B\) is less than the mean mass of cherries of Type \(A\). You should assume that the population variances for the two types of cherry are equal. [9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
<form>
